items.title: Follow the carbon, find the money: Turning sustainability into financial value

ai.summary: Based on the available description, Rich Goode of PwC US explains that sustainability gains traction when framed in business terms by linking carbon reductions to measurable financial impact. Translating emissions outcomes into cost savings and business value makes carbon concrete and helps move sustainability from ambition to action by driving alignment, investment, and results.
bullets: Frame sustainability in financial terms to engage leadership.
Link carbon reduction outcomes to cost savings and business value.
A ton of carbon is abstract; dollar impacts are concrete.
Translate emissions metrics into business outcomes to prompt action.
Understand carbon accounting fundamentals to communicate effectively.
takeaways: Convert emissions reductions into dollar impacts to secure executive buy-in and capital for upgrades.
Prioritize projects by emissions-to-financial-return to optimize investments in efficiency and renewables.
Establish basic carbon accounting to validate sustainability claims and demonstrate ROI.
Report sustainability outcomes in business metrics to align operations, procurement, and finance.

items.title: Bringing In $251K A Year With 3 Jobs In The Bay Area

ai.summary: Based on the available description, Naseema McElroy, 44, is a labor and delivery nurse in Brentwood, California who also runs a personal finance brand called Financially Intentional. She earned $251K a year working three jobs in the Bay Area, documented a journey from nearly $1 million in debt in 2015 to becoming debt-free by 2017, and is featured in CNBC Make It's Millennial Money series.
